results.description:
Let's go see the Pollock exhibition before it opens to the public and enjoy the quietness of the museum in the early hours!

You must have a current MoMA membership to RSVP for this event. 
Feel free to bring your friends if you like but know you have to pay for their guest tickets.  You can RSVP for yourself +5.
If you do bring guests please make sure to indicate in your RSVP how many will join you.

Corporate memberships do not qualify for admission during members only previews or members early hours.

Jackson Pollock: A Collection Survey, 1934–1954

This exhibition offers a concise but detailed survey of the work of Jackson Pollock (American, 1912–1956). It tracks his artistic evolution from the 1930s and early 1940s, when he made loosely figurative images based on mythical or primeval themes, to the late 1940s and early 1950s, when he pioneered the radical abstractions for which he is best known by pouring and dripping paint onto canvas or paper. The exhibition features approximately 50 works—paintings, drawings, and prints—from the Museum’s collection, which is unparalleled in the breadth, depth, and quality of its Pollock holdings. Among the paintings on view is One: Number 31, 1950 (1950), arguably Pollock’s greatest masterpiece, and one of his largest canvases. Exceedingly rare and little-known engravings, lithographs, screenprints, and drawings are also included, highlighting an underappreciated side of one of the most important and influential American artists of the 20th century. By bringing together works made using a range of materials and techniques—both traditional and unorthodox—the exhibition underscores the relentless experimentation and emphasis on process that was at the heart of Pollock’s creativity.

If there is interest, we will have a conversation over coffee afterwards.  There are two Starbucks withing walking distance.
results.name: POLLOCK AT MoMA - You MUST be a MoMA member to RSVP for this event.

results.description:
This volunteer opportunity helps a segment of the NYC population that is particularly vulnerable (our home-bound seniors) and is facing a steadily growing problem - hunger. As our city’s elderly grow older, they are more likely to have mobility limitations, while living at or below the poverty level. The elderly of East Harlem are particularly more vulnerable, residing in challenging living conditions alone, and who can no longer shop or cook for themselves.

Citymeals-on-Wheels (www.citymeals.org) raises private funds to ensure no homebound elderly New Yorker will ever go a day without food or human company. Citymeals funds 33 community-based agencies that bring weekend, holiday and emergency meals to homebound elderly New Yorkers - one of the agencies we'll be helping as volunteers.

How are we helping?

On Saturday, November 21st, we'll assist the Stanley Isaacs Senior Center Citymeals-on-Wheels program with delivery of meals to the elderly. Volunteers should wear weather appropriate clothes and comfortable shoes as deliveries are done on foot within walking distance from the meal center.  Although the weather may not always be favorable, the meals MUST be delivered as many, if not all, of the elderly in the program RELY on the meal delivery for the day.

Our Meetup

We'll meet at the Senior Center at 9:30am on Saturday for a short training, then break into small teams of 3 to 4 people to deliver the meals to the elderly. A light breakfast of juice, coffee, pastry and/or bagels will be offered.

If you RSVP, please try to be on time, or arrive no later than 9:30am, which is when we start delivery. The time commitment ends at 12pm and goes by very quickly. 

If you have any questions, running late, need more information on parking and etc., feel free to call/text Daniel at 774.275.3646.

Directions to the Union Settlement Senior Center

The Stanley Isaacs Senior Center is located at 415 East 93rd Street. The closest subway is the #6 train to 96th Street & Lexington Avenue, then walking east to 93rd street & 1st Avenue. The building is offset from the street (toward the FDR Drive), enter through sliding glass doors. The M15 bus line stops nearby, along 1st Avenue (uptown) or 2nd Avenue (downtown).

Thanks and see you there!

results.description:
Come join us for some challenging Rock Scrambling and Crevice Exploration at Mohonk Preserve and put your Rock Scrambling skills to the test! Though the mileage is relatively short, this is no average walk in the park!  You will get a full body workout while exploring the many crevices, towering rock walls and breakdown at Table Rocks and Bonticou Crag.


1) OUR FIRST STOP WILL BE AT TABLE ROCKS


WE WILL MEET AT THE SPRINGFARM TRAILHEAD @ MOHONK PRESERVE

Upper 27 Knolls Rd

High Falls, NY 12440

[masked], [masked]

http://www.mohonkpreserve.org/spring-farm-trailhead


Our adventure at Table Rocks: We will hike about 2 miles to arrive at the more remote and less visited Table Rocks area of the Mohonk Preserve for some Deep Crevice Exploration.  This area is pretty rugged with no set route so you can expect lots of challenging terrain as well as some exploration through some known and unknown routes. There are also some small dark crevices to explore for the more adventurous so be sure to bring a headlamp!


2) OUR SECOND STOP WILL BE AT BONTICOU CRAG

Our adventure at Bonticou Crag: From Table Rocks we will hike approximately 2-3 miles to Bonticou.  Bonticou Crag is like a giant playground of scrambles and climbs surrounded by beautiful views of the adjacent Catskills.  Bonticou also offers some small Talus caves beneath its breakdown for the more adventurous! (You might consider bringing some knee-pads, a helmet and a headlamp if you want to explore these.)  If you've ever been to Bonticou before you probably only touched the surface.  We will fully explore the area taking "trails" up and down the cliff face on the left, right and middle as well as scrambling through its breakdown for the entire length of the outcropping.


TOTAL DISTANCE: Approximately 7-8 miles

SCRAMBLING PACE: Slow but physically challenging (not to be confused with easy)

ESTIMATED HIKE/SCRAMBLE TIME: 7+ hours

DIFFICULTY: Intermediate - Rocky Terrain & Crevices with possible loose, slippery or jagged rocks. Must have a good sense of balance and not have an unnatural fear of heights

CURRENT WEATHER FORECAST:  Partly Sunny with a high of 47 degrees.

FEE: Please Note Mohonk Preserve charges a $12. fee for day use.  Season Passes are also available for $55. or $45. for students.  If you enjoy Mohonk preserve you can apply your $12. day usage fee towards the purchase of a membership by simply saving and submitting your bracelet (pass) within 2 weeks of purchase at the Visitor Center.


RECOMMENDED GEAR:

• Raincoat/Windbreaker and proper layering for 40-50 degree weather

• "Scrambling" Gloves - Lightweight with good grip - Gardening gloves from Home Depot work great!

• Shoes with good grip - preferably with ankle support

• Headlamp with spare batteries - Home Depot has a great 100 lumen headlamp for only $12.99!

• A Small Pack - nothing too large that will become a hindrance in the scrambles

• Related maps, a Compass or GPS, Water, Snacks, First Aid, etc.


OPTIONAL GEAR:

• Climbing Helmet (Bicycle helmet will do) Not mandatory but rocks could get kicked loose (especially recommended if you are clumsy or want to check out the Talus caves at Bonticou)


RELATED MAPS:

New York - New Jersey Trail Conference - Shawangunk Trails Map Set


**HEAVY RAIN WILL CANCEL THIS EVENT**

Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

Sat., Nov. 21: 10-12: Unusual Entrances to Park (#5) - OLD HOLLOW ROAD, MILLBURN

We will enter the park from Old Hollow Rd. in Millburn, which the Olmsteds planned on being the main Millburn entry into the park in 1902. This land is owned as undeveloped park land by the town of Millburn and there is no maintained trail. So we will be walking through brush and tall grass some of the time. Therefore long pants are a necessity. We come out of the woods at Hawk Hill in the Reservation and pick up the Elmdale Trail. After following it for a while we will circle around and return to our cars through Old Short Hills Park. Meet at: Old Short Hills Park, 274 Old Short Hills Rd, Millburn. The entrance to OSHP is on the right hand side of the road through a stone gateway 1.3 miles north of the RR bridge on Old Short Hills Rd. near the center of Millburn. Leader: Dave Hogenauer[masked]-0824.

REGISTER AT EVENTBRITE

Being the Infinite Self
A Day-long Channeled Workshop in Mastery

Award-winning author and channel Paul Selig will lead a deeply transformational, channeled workshop where you will work directly with his guides to achieve new levels of healing, self-awareness and life purpose. Through lectures, attunements, Q&A and energy work, Paul and his Guides will lead you through their program for personal conscious transformation.

In this workshop you will:

* Receive individual instruction and teaching from Paul’s Guides
* Become attuned to higher frequencies in ways that you can trust & feel
* Learn how to send and receive healing energies
* Free yourself from patterns of limitation and fear
* Gain tools to transform your life and awaken to your own divine nature

ABOUT PAUL

Paul Selig is a writer, empath and conscious channel. In his breakthrough works of channeled literature, I Am the Word, The Book of Love and Creation, and The Book of Knowing and Worth, he recorded an extraordinary program for personal and planetary evolution as humankind awakens to its own divine nature. Paul’s 4th channeled text, The Book of Mastery, will be released in January 2016 from Tarcher/Penguin. He has led channeled energy groups for nearly 20 years and maintains a private practice as a psychic in New York City. Paul’s recent and upcoming workshops include the Esalen Institute, the Omega Institute and the Kripalu Center. He was recently featured on the documentary series The uneXplained on the A&E/BIO channel.

LOCATION

Masonic Hall is located at 71 West 23rd Street at the NE corner of 6th Avenue. This is just steps from the F,M and Path Train station at 23rd Street and within walking distance from Penn Station. Grand Central Station is a 15 minute cab ride away. The workshop will be held on the 19th Floor in America’s Room.

PARKING

There is a parking garage located just down the street at 170 West 23rd Street (between 6th & 7th Avenues).

LUNCH

There will be a lunch break around 12.30 or 1 pm. Attendees are free to venture out on their own for lunch in the neighborhood. There are many options within walking distance. One easy and relatively inexpensive option for salads, sandwiches, soups and flatbread pizzas is called Cosi and is located just down the street at 700 6th Avenue between 22nd and 23rd Street (east side of the street).

QUESTIONS

Please email [masked] or call[masked]

Please note student discounts and the policies for workshop cancellations and age requirements.

REGISTER AT EVENTBRITE

This year's Anti-Fur Society Conference & Fashion Show will present special opportunities for ethical fashion traders, designers, models and beauticians to showcase their products. results.description:
Saturday and Sunday, November 21st and 22nd 2015 from 10am to 4pm

When the autumn leaves start to turn, and the crisp fall air is here, Thanksgiving is just around the corner, and it's time for Garvies Point Museum's NATIVE AMERICAN FEAST. This celebration of northeastern Native American culture has been held the weekend before Thanksgiving for more than 25 years.

sample native foods


spear throwing


use the atlatl


face painting


fire making


Native American Films


exhibits

cooking at the fire 


learn tool making


pottery making


dugout canoes


nature trails


artifacts


wigwam

Hands-on activities during the weekend will be on-going. These will include pottery-making using ancient methods, primitive fire-building and on-site open fire cooking with samples (including our famous popcorn soup). Authentic Native American food displays with sampling; artifacts and tool technology including drilling in stone, face painting with natural pigments, and spear throwing using an atlatl. Films about Native American culture will be shown throughout. Activities are appropriate for all ages. Activities are held both indoors and outdoors. 

Participants can also take this opportunity to view the museum's exhibition hall, which explores Long Island Native American culture and archeology, as well as New York State and Long Island geology. 

Fee: $5.00 for everyone above age 5. Children under 5 years of age are free with parent. 

Note: Rain or Shine.
results.name: Annual Native American (Thanksgiving) Feast

results.description:
This Saturday meet me at Prospect Park for a journey to the Socrates Sculpture Park in Queens.

We will meet at the Wilklow Orchards farm stand at the Prospect Park farmers market and ride through Brooklyn into Queens and journey through the Sculpture Park. Admission to Socrates is free and we can ride our bikes along the paths while checking out the art. We will then return to Prospect park- be sure to bring a few dollars to stop for some warm apple cider :) If you need to veer out of the pack at anytime, that is fine, just please let someone riding close to you know.

The roundtrip mileage is about 20 miles, with higher elevation closer to Prospect Park (144 ft). With dropping temperatures, please be sure to care for your extremities- liner socks, gloves and hats will keep the cold at bay and windbreakers/light jackets will help to maintain your core temperature.

Check out our blog for more temperature regulating tips: http://www.lifecyclebiking.com/blog-supply/2015/9/18/hey-autumn-welcome-back

Helmets are not required, but are strongly suggested as we will be following all rules of the road. Please feel free to message me with any questions or concerns. See you Saturday!
results.name: Socrates Sculpture Park

Regenerative Cities
Integrating the natural world with the urban environment
Saturday, November 21st 10am-5pm @ The Commons Brooklyn 388 Atlantic Ave 11217 -- $60

Transform your life and the city you live in to be healthier and more connected to nature. Andrew Faust, NYC’s renowned Permaculture scholar, will share his life experience of applying ecological design thinking to New York and all cities. You will gain a wealth of positive solutions for redesigning your home, lifestyle and neighborhood with permaculture in mind

Topic will include:
Rooftop gardening
Home water systems
Composting methods and techniques
Closing the loop of urban metabolisms
Diet and healthy food sources
Looking for land with permaculture insights
Researching pollution and health problems
Decentralized renewable power grids for cities

-- See you there!

results.description:
There is a wait list for this event.  To avoid the need to register for most events, you can join the TriState Ramblers Club for $15 a year, giving you access to a FULLER SCHEDULE of hikes, bike rides, and canoeing events 6 days a week, all year long.  Membership applications can be downloaded from the club website at http://tsr.nynjtc.org/   

NOTE CHANGE OF LEADER:  Now being led by Jay Dibble [masked])

Meet: 10 AM at the Dog Park adjacent to Crest Drive. Hike concludes about 12:15 PM. Hike down the hill to the Rahway River, then along the river to Locust Grove. From Locust Grove hike up the hill to reach the Lenape Trail, and follow it most of the way back to the Dog Park. Scenic highlight is Maple Falls and Cascades along the Lenape Trail. Hiking boots required. Bring water and a snack. Please arrive by 9:45 am. Watch this site on the morning of November 21 for any last minute changes/cancellations.
If this is your third meetup event with TSR we kindly ask that you join the club for $15 yearly membership with full access to our schedule which allows you to attend hikes and other outings 6 days a week. As a dues paying member of TSR you do not need to sign up for events and you do not have to be entered onto a waiting list. You can attend all events. Visit our website at tsr.nynjtc.org for an application and schedule preview.

DIRECTIONS:
SOUTH MOUNTAIN RESERVATION, Milburn and West Orange, NJ
These directions will get you into the park. Then see the detailed directions following and the map on the last page to find specific meeting places.
From east of the park (westbound) on I-78: Take exit 50 B "Millburn" "Maplewood". At the end of the ramp, you must go right. Drive through 3 traffic lights, not counting the one at the end of the ramp. At the fourth light (Millburn Ave.), turn left. Drive to the second traffic light (the road makes a turn to the right and becomes a one way street called Essex Ave.). Turn right onto Lackawanna Place, go under the RR tracks, and you come almost immediately to Glen Ave. Across the street and a little to the right is a drive way entering the park with a sign "Locust Grove". For all other areas of the park, turn left and go to the first traffic light and turn right onto Brookside Drive. (see map and following directions)
From west of the park (eastbound) on I-78 or NJ 24: NJ 24 joins I[masked]/2 miles before exit 49B "Maplewood." At the end of the ramp you must go to the right on Springfield Ave. (NJ 124). At the first light in 0.4 miles, you must take a jug handle to the right in order to turn left onto Valley Street. At the next light in 0.3 miles turn, left onto Vauxhall Road. Proceed 0.2 miles to the next light which is Millburn Ave. and turn left Then follow the directions as in "From the east on Interstate 78” above.
From north of the park (either eastbound or westbound) on I-280: Take exit 7. At the bottom of the ramp, Turn south (left) onto Pleasant Valley Way. Proceed 2.2 miles to the corner of Pleasant Valley Way and Northfield Ave. Turn right for Mayapple Hill, left for Turtle Back Rock Picnic Area, and straight ahead for all other parts of the park (see map and directions below).
1. Dog Park (formerly called Deer Paddock): From Brookside Drive & South Orange Ave. intersection, Millburn, (Follow signs to the Dog Park, to get there) take South Orange Ave. east (toward South Orange) about 1 mile, just past traffic light, to Crest Drive on right. Go 0.6 miles to barricade. Turn right to parking lot.
results.name: HIKE - South Mountain Res/Dog Park, West Orange

results.description:
Pre-Thanksgiving Dance Walk. Bring your own ipod & earbuds. We dance walk around the park loop--everybody listens to their own music. What is dance walking? It's an improvised form of walking, with music, doing whatever movement comes naturally. It's walking and moving your arms. Or skipping, skitching, low-stepping, sideways running. It's responding to the rhythm, attitude, or story of the music you're hearing. In short, it's having a dance party in your living room, while walking through the park--hilarious and exhilarating. For inspiration, check out:

www.24hoursofhappy.com
results.how_to_find_us: From the farmer's market in Grand Army Plaza, walk up the drive toward the park loop. We meet about 50 paces up the drive, just shy of the park loop
results.name: Dance Walk in Prospect Park--Saturday November 21 @10am

results.description:
Studying for the application process at Grace Hopper Academy? Join us for a workshop that takes you through the coding assessment step-by-step. We'll review the challenges and run through practice problems, answering questions along the way. 

At the end of the session, you'll feel more confident in your skills and be ready to take the next step towards becoming a developer. 

Get a better sense for the application requirements in the Admissions Prep Materials for Grace Hopper Academy: gracehopper.com/admissions-preparation 

Workshop Agenda

1. Welcome from Instructors of Grace Hopper Academy

2. Test-taking strategies: tips on how to ace the admissions coding assessment

3. Coding Challenges: attendees will pair up to solve the 5+ problems in 20 minute blocks

4. Each problem will be followed by a 10 minute review to address the solution

5. Attendees will leave the workshop having completed several coding challenges and receive Review Videos

Reminders

• Bring a computer!

• Workshop begins at 10am on Saturday

Please arrive on time to maximize the effectiveness of the workshop

If you are a beginner, we recommend you complete as many of the following units 1, 2, 3, 5 and 6 of Codecademy's JavaScript track as possible before Saturday.

Grace Hopper Academy is the world’s first immersive coding school for women where students only pay tuition after securing a job. Our mission is to close the gender gap in technology through high-quality education, mentorship, and need-blind admissions. With a proven curriculum and educational program leveraged from partner school Fullstack Academy, Grace Hopper Academy offers an open environment for women to learn software development and become professional engineers.
results.name: Grace Hopper Academy Admissions Prep Workshop

As always, we are working very hard to make this an enjoyable event for everyone.

Price - $40 which includes:

3 feet of cropping space.

Coffee and tea will be available all day, as well as candy.

Raffles and fabulous prizes!!!

Gifts! 

Fun games!

Tool Station:  Cricut and an assortment of cartridges, (please bring your own mats), and Cuttlebug machines will be available. 

We have the following Cricut Cartridges:  Accent Essentials, A Child's Year, All Mixed Up, Alphalicious, Animal Kingdom, Baseball, Base Camp, Beyond Birthdays, Blackletter, Camp Out, Celebrations, Christmas Cheer, Cursive 101, Cuttin' Up, Disney & Friends, Doodlecharms, Everyday Paper Dolls, Fabulous Finds, Forever Young, From My Kitchen, George, Going Places, Home Decor, Indie Art, Jasmine, Joys of the Season, Jubilee, Life's A Beach, Locker Talk, Love Struck, Lyrical Letters, Making The Grade, Meow, Mother's Day, My Community, My World, Old West, Opposites Attract, Pagoda, Paisley, Paper Dolls Dressup, Plantin Schoolbook, Printing Press, Printing Press 101, Pumpkin Carving, Simply Sweet, Songbird, Speaking of Fall, Sports Mania, Stand & Salute, Stamping, Stretch Your Imagination, Walk In My Garden, Wild Card, Winter Woodland, Wedding.

If you would like a specific one to be available at the crop, please message us and we will be sure to have it on hand for you. 

Vendors Pending!!! 

We are also working on getting a licensed chiropractor to do massage therapy!  Please indicate your interest if you would like a massage as that will decide his attendance. 

Space is limited to 19 spots which are on a first come, first served basis and are not guaranteed unless you have paid. Checks and cash will not be accepted.  Non-refundable fee required at time of RSVP.

Tell us who you would like to sit with and we will do our best to accommodate everyone's request.

The hotel has various sandwiches, wraps, snacks and beverages available for sale but you may also order in from local area restaurants which will deliver.  You may bring your own food as there is a microwave for your use.  Please note, however, no refrigeration available. 

Bring your scrap-maBob drink holder.

Remember extension cords if you require electricity for your devices. 

On-site valet parking available for a reduced rate.

We hope to see you there!

results.description:
Hello Everyone

Jeremy Ogusky from Boston Ferments will be in town for an FREE fermentation talk and Kraut Mob at the new Museum of Food and Drink in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. 


Hope to see some of you there!

Best,

Angela Davis

NYC Ferments, Co-organizer

Kraut Mob with Boston Ferments and Jeremy Ogusky


From kimchi to kombucha, fermented foods are all the rage these days. These foods are not only delicious and healthy, they’re also easy to make at home. Join us for a family-friendly, hands-on fermentation workshop. Fearless fermenter and studio potter Jeremy Ogusky will explain the health benefits and craft of lacto-fermentation. Jeremy will show you how to create your own sauerkraut, one of the simplest of pickles. You will also go home with your own jar of fermenting, soon-to-be-funky cabbage.

This event is FREE and open to the public. Please RSVP here: https://www.showclix.com/event/kraut-mob

Click here for directions.
results.name: Kraut Mob with Boston Ferments and Jeremy Ogusky

Lunches, we can use 5-10 volunteers from 9:30am-2:30pm on weekdays

 for food preparation, sorting/organizing incoming food and clothing donations, meal setup, serving one lunch meal and general cleaning projects.

 Volunteers must be over the age of 15.

  Additionally, we offer the opportunity for corporate groups to donate the operational price of one meal—around $500. This contribution provides[masked] meals for homeless families and individuals across the city of New York. If this opportunity is one in which you and your organization would like to engage in, I would be happy to connect you to my colleague Laurie-Anne, who can take care of any invoicing necessary for your tax-deductable gift.

  Best,

  Sarah Edmiston

Code Crew introduces Intro to JavaScript Programming: Intensive Workshop

Curious about Javascript and what the powerful programming language has to offer? Join us for an intensive one-day crash course where you’ll be immersed in the language through a mixture of brief lectures and programming exercises.

This course is perfect for aspiring developers or entrepreneurs with no technical experience or those looking to get a refresher in JavaScript. 

What You'll Learn: 

• Learn syntax and key programming concepts such as the use of variables, data types, conditional statements, loops, functions, arrays and objects to build a dynamic program.

• Learn the basics of Object-Oriented Programming in JavaScript.

• Learn how to work with the Chrome Inspector and JavaScript console to debug your code

Then we will have lunch by 164th-168th and for those who are interested by, 'the grand finale' would be to attend a Hip Hop version of the Nutcracker at the United Palace...The New York Times described it as "magical" with "touches of poetry" and "a gift to Upper Manhattan." Time Out New York called it “a classic rebooted.”

Plus the United Palace is so far the most extravagant/beautiful theatre I have ever seen. Have a look on Google images at « United Palace » : An amazing place (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Palace)

results.description:
"Picasso Sculpture" is a sweeping survey of Pablo Picasso’s innovative and influential work in three dimensions. This is the first such museum exhibition in the United States in nearly half a century.

Let's start by meeting at Starbucks, to introduce ourselves over coffee.

Then we'll go over to MOMA, to see the Picasso Sculpture show.  Check out Roberta Smith's glowing review in the NY Times:


http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/11/arts/design/review-picasso-sculpture-moma-museum-of-modern-art.html?_r=0

I'm hoping we can more or less synchronize our viewing pace, so that we can see--and share--and comment on--this exhibit. 


FYI, the exhibit is large...it takes up a whole floor.


Attendees are responsible for paying for any purchases from Starbucks, and for the special $5 guest rate to enter MOMA on my membership pass.  That's right, you will save $20 vs. the normal $25 admission price! 


If something comes up and you can't attend, please change your RSVP status as soon as possible.  Given the small size of this meetup group, no-show's would be a big loss.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet inside Starbucks at 1290 Sixth Ave, entrance on 52nd St, between 5th & 6th Ave.  I will display a red Meetup sign.
results.name: Connect by Seeing the Amazing "Picasso Sculpture" Show at MOMA

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Greeting to all our Bellydance enthusiasts! I would like to invite you all to come out and enjoy a wonderful day celebrating the wonderful art of Bellydance at this festival hosted by Audie OS. This is the second year she has hosted this event and it is sure to be a fun filled day. I will be teaching a wonderful fun filled workshop on Egyptian Baladi style dance as well as performing in the evening show. Here is the itinerary of the day:

Experience Belly Dance and Drumming Workshops and Performances in this day long festival with nationally renowned artists. Shop the amazing vendors for Dance wear, Costumes Accessories, Drums and Drumming supplies. After the workshops students have the opportunity to perform in the evening showcase.

Workshops

1: Practice –Practice -Drillin’ the Basics, Audie

How do you become an excellent dancer? Practice –Practice – Practice! Join Audie as she breaks down and drill the core movements of Belly Dance. This workshop is open to students of all levels. Beginners will be able to focus on the main tenants of the dance. Experienced dancers will be able to hone their skills and perfect their techniques. 

11-12:30PM, $25

2: Authentic Egyptian Beladi Basics. Tarik Sultan
This class focuses on how to dance with the emotion and passion that will give your dance that authentic look and feel. Students will also learn how to coordinate their hands and arms to frame and enhance their movements giving their dance a natural and spontaneous flow. Whether your style is Fusion, Tribal, Turkish or American Cabaret the skills learned in this class will take you to a higher level -alive with charisma, passion and personality!
3:00-5:30PM, $50

3: The Art of Frame Drumming Obi Kaye
From Beginner to Advanced , learn the traditions and techniques or frame percussion in the Mediteranean and Middle East. From Moroccan Bend it to the Iranian Dad, participants will learn the rhythms of Egyptian Riq and Turkish Tar and more. Course will include the Ayyoub, Beledi, Debra, Hindi, Laz, Chiftatelli. Masmoudi and more. Obi’s teaching technique makes it simple and fun. 12-2:30PM, $50

4: Who’s Afraid of the Big Bad Drum Solo? Casey Bond
Belly Dance drummers and drum-curious dancers are invited to join percussionist Casey Bond for a fun workshop! Beginner and intermediate drummers and dancers welcome- let’s have fun with drums and zills! Everyone will participate as we deconstruct and demystify basic drum solo patterns. Dancers will learn tips and techniques guaranteed to help you overcome the anxiety associated with dancing to live percussion. Drummers will learn some solid, sure fire drum solo patterns! Bring a doumbek, bass doumbek or zills and your sense of adventure. 
3:00-5:30PM, $50

5: Join the Tribe with ATS Basics Maria Naja Richards
This intensive workshop will consist of the dance fundamentals movements of American Tribal Style ® belly dance according to the Fat Chance Format. This includes learning the formations and being able to improvise dance on the spot with these basic movements. 12-2:30PM, $50
Pricing
Registration opens August 3rd 
Early Registration Discount ends Sept. 3st 
1.5 hour class $20. 2.5 hour classes $40. Evening Showcase $5. 
Full Day Package: 3 workshops, Showcase (one 1.5 hour workshop and two 2.5 hour workshops) and a Gift Bag $100.
Almost Early Registration Discount ends Oct. 15th 
1.5 hour class $20. 2.5 hour classes $45. Evening Showcase $5. 
Full Day Package: 3 workshops and Showcase (one 1.5 hour workshop and two 2.5 hour workshops) $110
Regular Price after Oct 15th.
1.5 hour class $25. 2.5 hour classes $50. Evening Showcase $10. 
Full Day Package: 3 workshops and Showcase (one 1.5 hour workshop and two 2.5 hour workshops. $120 
Location: ABCC 554 Bloomfield Ave Bloomfield, NJ

Online Registration is now open: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/bellyrhythm-middle-eastern-dance-drum-festival-tickets-18022830772

results.description:
www.facebook.com/events/[masked]


The holidays are nearly upon us again, and with November being Thanksgiving, what better way to celebrate than with some good company and two whole days of rubber monster suits and good old fashioned stop motion animation?

B-movies and Thanksgiving have gone hand in hand for decades, with New York's own WOR-TV, along with other stations, often playing classic King Kong and Godzilla movies on TV around the holiday, firmly cementing the connection in the minds of many between gathering with the family for Thanksgiving dinner and then watching old school B-movies on television afterwards.

Come join us on Saturday and Sunday for the first (hopefully annual) Thanksgiving B-Movie Festival! Starting at 11:00am, we'll be screaming a bunch of krazy different old school B-movies and regional independent films.

To cover the cost of venue rental and other charges we're charging $10 per person. This isn't per day, or per movie. It's for the Entire Festival!!

SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 21st:


11:00 am - TRAILER MANIA - A collection of B-movie and horror trailers spanning the decades from the 1950s to the 1990s.

11:30 am - DESTROY ALL MONSTERS! (in Japanese with English subtitles)


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r_rWm_u2oQQ

1:00 pm - REPTILICUS  (the world's only Danish giant monster movie!)


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0DR01wDvGVA

2:30 pm - PLANET OF DINOSAURS - Futuristic explorers crash land on a distant planet and battle stop-motion dinosaurs in this 1978 low-budget gem.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S2DqiQtWuDA

4:00 pm - THE LEGEND OF BOGGY CREEK - The famous docudrama by Charles B. Pierce, about the legendary Bigfoot-like monster that resides in Fouke, Arkansas.


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E9V44D9xZ70

5:30 pm - THE DEADLY SPAWN - The low-budget New Jersey gore-fest with outstanding practical creature effects by John Dods! (The X-Files, Spookies, "Monsters" TV show)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=agtrqXBfiE4


SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 22nd:


10:00 am - REVENGE OF TRAILER MANIA!  More B-movie and horror trailers from the 1950s through the 1990s!

10:30 am - SUPER INFRAMAN - The mind-boggling and fast paced Hong Kong monster mash action film, about the super hero Inframan fighting off the monster armies of the evil Dragon Queen! A must see!


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qx81E2Wnig0

Noon - EQUINOX - The stop-motion cult classic that directly inspired Sam Raimi and Bruce Campbell when making the Evil Dead.


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tctHCMAi8jw

1:30 pm - FROSTBITER: WRATH OF THE WENDIGO  -  A fun creature feature horror-comedy from the late 90s, featuring Ron Asheton, former guitarist for Iggy Pop, and directly inspired by the classic Evil Dead 2.


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lvwkeJH0SuA

3:00 pm - The Giant Claw - the biggest turkey of them all in the notorious 1950s sci-fi monster movie!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IRqjSBKIhtc

4:30 pm - BLOOD FREAK - How could we possibly end with anything else? Perfect for Thanksgiving, the world's only pro-Jesus, anti-drug, killer turkey monster movie!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xVJDDK05f0I
results.name: Thanksgiving B-Movie Festival!!

results.description:
Please join LI-DOG for our final Pack Walk of the 2015 season as we walk the grounds of the beautiful 216-acre former estate of the Guggenheim family--Sands Point Preserve! Our Pack Walks are a great way for both you and your dog to socialize, while enjoying some of Long Island’s most beautiful parks. We'll resume our Pack Walks in the Spring!

This Pack Walk will take approximately one hour--there are opportunities to opt out for those who want to make the walk shorter--as we walk past Castle Gould and onto the wooded trails. These trails may be a bit steep at times and have roots and rocks, but there’s a great overlook of the LI Sound at the top. We’ll then walk down to the pond, out to the Sound for another view, then back past Hempstead House where we started. Please note: dogs are not allowed on the beach and must remain leashed at all times. Please do not bring Flexi Leads as we’ll be walking in groups and people and dogs can get tangled. Also, please bring water and poop bags—as clean up is a must.

Photos: There will be great photo opportunities for you and your dog, so bring your camera and please post your photos here on Meetup or on our Facebook Group.

Admission: Sands Point charges $10 per car or per “walk-in” unless you have their annual pass. This fee helps preserve this wonderful piece of Long Island history. For more info about Sands Point, go to http://thesandspointpreserve.com/.

Please arrive by 10:45 a.m., so we can begin the walk at 11.

We hope to see everyone and their dogs on the 21st!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the people and dogs on the big field near the parking!
results.name: LI-DOG November Pack Walk at Sands Point Preserve!

results.description:
Veg Dim Sum Brunch & Chinatown Temple Tour

This is one of our favorite annual events.  We'll have a pre-Thanksgiving brunch at Vegetarian Dim Sum House.  After dim sum, for those who are interested, we will do an informal tour of the Buddhist Temples in Chinatown. This will probably last 1.5 hr so we will likely finish the tour around 2:30 pm.

Date: November 21st,


Time: 11 am

Place: Vegetarian Dim Sum House
(This restaurant is vegan friendly)

Price: Estimated at $12-$15 per person, you can share or attempt to get your own check with the wait staff.

We will promptly enter at 11am. Remember that the MTA runs at a slower pace during the weekend.

We plan to visit five Buddhist temples, including oldest Buddhist temple in the East Coast, a Buddha statue believed to be the largest in the City (in temples!), and a statue of Eleven-Head Thousand-Arm Bodhisattva of Compassion or Avalokitesvara. These temples have served the local community for nearly half a century.  

We'll go inside the temple if we can, however if there are any service at the temples, we will stay outside.  Remember, it will be a brisk autumn day so dress warmly and of course, wear comfortable walking shoes.

American Society of Buddhist Studies (Chan, 1974)

See you soon,

Eddie

Market on Market is a fun and exciting new monthly Art/Flea Market in Downtown Newark, NJ. Modeled after many other fantastic markets in Trenton, Brooklyn, Beacon and Philadelphia; Market on Market offers handmade, upcycled, recycled and antique items as well as workshops and events.

Art | Handmade Stuff | Crafts Vintage | Retro | Antiques | Junk/Salvage | Architectural Elements Collectibles | Books Records | Prints | Costume Jewelry | Musical Instruments Tools | Art Supplies | Buttons and Pins | Wellness & Beauty Products | Limited Editions | Yoga | FUN

Modeled after other fantastic markets, Market on Market offers handmade, upcycled, recycled and antique items as well as workshops and musical events. Over 40 vendors attend the market, and although some come back for each market, there is always a good rotation of new vendors each month. results.description:
This week we’ll explore the fourth of the Ten Perfections - Wisdom. 

Defining wisdom can be a little challenging. Typically, we see it as a combination of knowledge, insight and judgment that work together. But a more expanded view is needed.

If we imagine a wisdom spectrum, we might start on one end with "common sense," that kind of everyday know-how formed from experience and some native ability. On the other end of the spectrum there would be the expanding breadth and depth of understanding and acquired knowledge that is creative and intuitive. This expanded ability makes it possible to see and tolerate the big picture with all of life's ambiguities and constantly changing nature with a sense of balance and equanimity. 

In the Buddhist context there are some specific and particular focal points that are foundational to the development of wisdom. The first important element, particularly from Tibetan traditions, is that wisdom travels with and is deeply intermingled with compassion. The image they use is the two wings of a bird of awakening. Diana Gould writes that "wisdom without compassion can be dry and indifferent; compassion without wisdom an be mushy, saccharine and maudlin." Compassion is our natural inclination and readiness to share with people who are suffering because, just like them, we have known suffering. Buddhist tradition is always aimed at living a life that is beneficial to other beings and to ourselves. Working together, Wisdom and Compassion are a powerful force.The Ten Perfections are important mind/body qualities or strengths that we can cultivate in any life situation and on the cushion.  When we make these Perfections our priority in life, they support us on our journey toward awake awareness.      

The Ten Perfections or qualities of mind are:

Generosity (Giving)
Virtue (Morality/Ethics)
Renunciation (Letting go of obstacles to awakening)
Wisdom (Discernment)
Energy (Effort)
Patience (Endurance)
Truthfulness
Determination/Resolution
Loving Kindness/Goodwill
Equanimity (Impartiality and balance)

The brief topic discussion will be followed by a guided meditation and time for discussion and Q&A.  Please note that while there is benefit in participating in regular sittings and practice, you do not have to attend every class to find value. I hope you'll join us.


Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 and your generosity is greatly appreciated.  No one is ever turned away for lack of funds.  The donation box is on the sign-in table.
results.name: The Ten Perfections - Wisdom

This 2-Day comprehensive workshop explores visual storytelling with dynamic camera movement and skillful actor blocking.


Through extensive, daily hands-on exercises, participants will learn to visualize the scene, work with actors, strategize with storyboards, and evoke the essence of the script: DRAMA!

Participants will learn how to visualize, choose optimum camera positions, camera movement, and lens choices in relations with actor blocking.

Through this process, participants will understand how to convey tone, mood, and style, as well as give the film a distinct look that belongs to the director's unique vision.

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.

WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...

1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play elsewhere, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated

9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved

Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.


WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

With winter just around the corner, a wonderful and tasty stew is a great way to enjoy the last of this great season!

I will be teaching how to make the classic hot pot of Akita
prefecture, in the northern region of Japan. The hot pot, with seasonal vegetables and fish or chicken will surely keep you warm for Winter.

You will learn how easy it is to create tasty Japanese food without going through complicated procedures. Certain key techniques will be demonstrated.

The most important thing in my class is that you are having fun while you learn. After cooking is done, you will enjoy the dishes you cooked.

The menu:
Kiritanpo hot pot with chicken and vegetables
Kaburamushi steamed grated Japanese turnip with vegetables in dashi
Seasonal vegetable salad
Green tea pudding

Let's Do Brunch!

Meet and network with WISE women at Reservations For Success with our guest presenter Dhamana M. Shakespeare-Turner, Business & Career Consultant. We're filling up quickly so be sure to reserve your seat now! http://bit.ly/1GgQtNz

Get ready to "Elevate Your Elevator Pitch" 

Being an entrepreneur and business owner, we wear many hats. We’re eager and motivated to expand and gain more customers! Then, the dreaded question: “So, what do you do?” Rather than stumbling for a general answer, or rambling about all of your tasks, make time to craft an actual elevator pitch!

“Elevate Your Elevator Pitch” is a designed for individuals seeking to learn the basics of creating a core elevator pitch, customizing their message and implementing strategies for communicating the right message, to the right person.  Show your value and unique opportunity!

Reserve your spot today! http://bit.ly/1GgQtNz

About Reservations For Success 

Reservations for Success features prominent women business leaders from the tri-state area. Networking and brunch will precede a presentation on such topics as marketing, branding, financing, social media, business networking, leadership and more.

Our brunches are held at Ashton's Alley, 825 3rd Ave, (On 50th B/W 2nd and 3rd), New York, NY 10022 and is an intimate gathering of 8-10 women that provides a comfortable discussion environment and maximum opportunities for each participant.

For only $35.00 (includes brunch menu meal, tax and tip), you get 2 hours of unlimited drinks (Mimosa, Bloody Mary, Screwdriver or coffee and tea) plus your choice of any food item on the brunch menu. You can view the menu at:http://ashtonsalleysportsbar.com/brunch-menu.html.

P.S. They have free wireless internet so bring in your laptops and tablets!

Advance Booking Required. Space is limited so please book early!

results.description:
Have you ever looked closely to plants in central park? Central Park is the most popular of parks for foragers. Because of its varied habitats and the combination of wild and cultivated, native, and exotic plants, Central Park is a great place to forage, especially in harvesting season, which is NOW!

For more info & To book tickets: https://goo.gl/Gj64g

Here are some things to keep in mind:

-Walks are called off for severely inclement weather. 
-Must be punctual and on-time! 
-BRING plastic bags for vegetables and herbs, paper bags for mushrooms, plastic containers for berries, drinking water, and a pen (to sign in). 
-No sandals (there may be poison ivy, bugs, and thorns). 
-NO SMOKING AT ANY TIME! 
-RECOMMENDED: Lunch, knife, digger, work gloves, note pad, whistle (so you won't get lost), insect repellent, sun hat or warm. 
-LISTEN to the weather forecast and dress appropriately. Bring one more layer of clothing than you think you'll need in cold weather. 
-CHILDREN of all ages are encouraged to attend, and to learn to understand and love their planet.

*******Please remember that this Meetup listing may not have accurate information - the people who have RSVPed may not have PAID/SIGNED UP. Please check attached link for the most accurate details!
results.name: Let's Learn How to Forage in the Heart of the Urban Jungle, Central Park!

results.description:
NOTE: We originally planned to visit Old Richmondtown. But it's under construction this weekend. So here's the revised itinerary, including an earlier meeting time (11:45 AM):

We'll take the free ferry (plus a 20-minute MTA train ride) to the fascinating heart of Staten Island. (Don't be late: Ferry leaves promptly at 12 noon.)  

First we'll walk about 30 minutes from the train station to a heavily wooded LaTourette Park, part of the S.I. Greenbelt. Then we'll walk through the forest for about an hour and a half; we'll have lunch outdoors in the woods. Next we'll walk through a lovely neighborhood to the Jacques Marchais Museum of Tibetan Art, with buildings and gardens designed to resemble a Himalayan mountain monastery. Jacques was actually a pioneering woman who designed the museum and amassed its collection during the 1930s and '40s. To me, this "museum" is more authentic and inspiring than Manhattan's glitzier but more sterile Rubin Museum of Tibetan Art. Then we'll visit the only home in NYC built by Frank Lloyd Wright. Finally we'll return to the ferry terminal by a bus near the Tibetan museum. 

NOTE: Don't worry about the seemingly huge group. Far fewer than that will actually show up. 

Please read the following details, so you're properly prepared:


LUNCH: Bring your own. We'll eat at about 1:30 PM. 


DISTANCE: About five miles.

PACE: Moderate (2 mph) NOT SLOW. WE MUST WALK MODERATELY OR WE'LL END UP WALKING IN THE DARK. 

ENDING TIME: We'll probably get back to the ferry terminal in Lower Manhattan at around 6:30 PM. But you can leave earlier, by catching a bus after the Tibet Museum if you wish; it leaves somewhere between 3 and 3:30 PM.

COST: $4 (special group rate) for the Tibetan museum, $5.50 round trip for the train and bus (unless your metrocard is unlimited), and $2 for me, in part to cover Meetup's organizer fee.


TRANSPORTATION TO FERRY TERMINAL: The number 1 train is not running to the ferry terminal. For alternatives consult mta.tripplanner.org, Google Transit (maps.google.com/landing/transit/index.html) or both, since each is occasionally inaccurate. Also consult a subway map, since the above sites may not list the best alternatives for you (and may not even know the number 1 isn't running in lower Manhattan).
results.how_to_find_us: We'll meet right inside the main entrance on the ground floor (before you reach the escalators), in the front left corner.
results.name: S.I. forest, Tibet museum, Frank Lloyd Wright & other mansions & old cemeter

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

results.description:
Join us as we gather to get to know one another and to discuss the glad tidings of the Kingdom of God as is noted in the scripture of truth.

 The Gospel of Jesus Christ is the glad tidings of the kingdom of God unto the meek, liberty to the captives, and the opening of the prison to them that are bound, the proclamation of the day of salvation, the acceptable year of the Lord (Is 52:6-7, 61:1-2, Luke 4:18-19, 8:1); whereby God sent and anointed his son Jesus Christ to preach the Gospel and to be the saviour of the world. (1 John 4:14) The Gospel of Jesus Christ is the power of God unto salvation to everyone that believes whether Jew or Greek (Rom 1:16-17) to all them that call upon him (Rom 10:12-15). For therein is the righteousness of God revealed from faith to faith.  The Gospel declares that Christ died for our sins according to the scriptures, he was buried, and rose again the third day according to the scriptures, that he was seen of Cephas, the twelve and then of five hundred brethren at once. (1 Cor 15:1-3) Through the Gospel we understand that that the stone which was rejected is become the head of the corner.  Jesus Christ who was rejected and crucified rose again the third day according to the scriptures, and is now exalted far above all principalities and powers (Ps 118:22-23, Mat 21:42, Acts 4:10-12, 1 Cor 15:1-3, Eph 1:20-21). We must know with all assurance that God hath made Jesus both Lord and Christ. (Acts 2:36, 4:26) This tried stone is none other than Jesus Christ; whose name is called Wonderful, Counsellor, The Mighty God, The everlasting Father, The Prince of Peace. (Is 7:10-14, Mat 1:21-23; Is 8:10-18, 9:6-7; 1 Pet 2:4-8). This is the true God and eternal life. (1 Jn 5:20)

  Jesus Christ came preaching repentance and that the kingdom of heaven is at hand (Mat 4:17). In order to enter into the kingdom of God we must be born again of the water and of the Spirit as Jesus told Nicodemus (Jn 3:3-5). Those early disciples in the book of Acts were born again when they repented, were baptized in the name of Jesus Christ, and received the infilling of the Holy Ghost. (Acts 2:37-41, 8:12-17, 9:17-18, 10:44-48, 19:1-6) The baptisms in the book of Acts were done in the name of Jesus Christ (Acts 2:38, 4:12, 8:12, 10:48, 19:5, Gal 3:27, Rom 6:3-4, Col 2:12). In order to obey the Gospel and enter into the kingdom of God we too must do what those early disciples did and what Jesus commanded. Repent therefore, and be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ for the remission of your sins and you too shall receive the gift of the Holy Ghost (Acts 2:38-39). Please take the time to look up the scriptures listed in this study. (Acts 17:11)

results.description:
Knickerbocker Bar & Grill, located in the heart of Greenwich Village, is a neighborhood favorite. Established in 1977, its popularity has grown over the years, due to its moderate prices and large portions.

Its wood paneled walls sport a wonderful collection of memorabilia with a New York state of mind. Pieces range from rare turn of the century posters to original caricatures by Al Hirschfield. Large leather booths line the walls and brass rails accent the 100 year old marble bar, where Charles Lindbergh signed his contract to fly across the Atlantic.


 Knickerbocker is known for its great Jazz and its 28 oz. T- Bone Steaks, and is a favorite among many celebrities. In recent articles, F. Murray Abraham and Ben Stiller mentioned it as among their favorite. Rachel Ray, from The Food network, has on several occasions praised our Shrimp Cocktail, Creamed Spinach and of course our T- Bone Steaks. Other frequent celebrities include Chris Noth, Josh Charles, Richard Gere, Alec Baldwin, Susan Sarandon, Jane Curtain and Paul Sorvino, cast and crew of  "The Good Wife."

Knickerbocker Bar & Grill - 12:00pm

33 University Pl (bet. 8th St & 9th St)

(212)[masked]

http://www.knickerbockerbarandgrill.com/#!brunch/c6sf


***PLEASE BRING SMALL BILLS (1's, 5's, 10's) to help facilitate payment.

***We will be getting sitting at 3 tables of 10.  Each table will receive 2 checks so there will be 5 people on each check.  You ONLY PAY for what you eat and drink + tax + tip (probably 18 - 20%)

***Please do not only bring a $20 bill hoping for change, it just doesn't work.


After brunch...


This should be a lovely meetup. I hope you can join us for brunch and shopping/browsing at the holiday market. 

Ivy



SUBWAY  (check mta.info/weekender for subway changes/updates the night before)

Take the R or N train to 8 Street

Take the 4 or 6 train to Astor Place

Take the R or L train to 14th St - Union Square

Take the A, B, C, D, E, F, M to West 4th St - Washington Square

***Walk to the restaurant at 9th St & University Place

MEETUP FEE:  $2.00 payable at the restaurant to defray the cost of maintaining the group  (EXACT CHANGE PLEASE)



PERFUME ALLERGY: Please REFRAIN from wearing perfume. Thank you for understanding.

results.description:
That biannual gift from the football gods called El Clásico is once again upon us ... and this one's simple enough: we win, we're top of the table ... VAMOS REAL!!!

Now, NYC-Madridistas, as most of you know, the party (i.e. the craziness) gets started way before kick-off, so please get to Quinn's super EARLY - we suggest to all our Official Peña Members to arrive by 10:30am at the latest!

For further important info on this event, please read below.

****

Please RSVP ASAP so that Quinn's can staff the event appropriately.

****

INSTRUCCIONES EN ESPAÑOL PARA TURISTAS, MIRAD MAS ABAJO:


Game begins at 12:15 PM EST, but we STRONGLY encourage you and your guest(s) to please arrive MUCH, MUCH earlier and enjoy the pre-game atmosphere at Quinn's.


Please read:

1. All Madridistas are welcome and entrance is free. Anyone with Barça apparel/flags will NOT be allowed in the bar. Also, if you're an OPM, please do NOT bring any friends/relatives that are Barça fans - there are no excuses for this, and your party will not be welcomed inside.

2. Official Peña Members (OPM) and ONLY ONE (1) guest will have entrance and placement priority in the downstairs area with RSVP if arriving at least 30 min. before the game. Please bring your membership card! If you are not an official member, you will be directed upstairs, see below.

3. Basic Meetup Members, tourists, and occasional visitors will be accommodated upstairs on a first-come/first-serve basis. For this group, we recommend that you come at least one (1) to two (2) hours before the game if you want to be seated. Basic Members PLEASE RSVP to have an idea of how many people to expect.

4. The UPPER90 truck, our partners, will be right outside Quinn's selling our Peña goodies and memberships (inc. the classic black-shirts and scarves) as well as other RealMadrid apparel - so leave some time before and during the festivities to pay them a visit. 

Hala Madrid, a por ellos!!!

INSTRUCCIONES PARA TURISTAS:


1. Todos los Madridistas están bienvenidos hasta que se llene el bar, la entrada es gratis pero NO se permitirá acceso a banderas/camisetas del Barça. Si su amigo/pariente es del Barça y está interesado en ver el Clásico, puede verlo en el local del Barça (Smithfield-NYC) o en cualquier otro sports bar de NYC.

2. Los miembros oficiales de la Peña que reserven asistencia y un (1) invitado tendrán prioridad de entrada. El area de abajo estará reservada sólo para los miembros oficiales.

3. Turistas, vistantes ocasionales y curiosos serán acomodados en el segundo nivel del bar, en orden de llegada. Para este grupo recomendamos que lleguen por lo menos una (1) o dos (2) horas antes del partido si quieren sentarse.

4. UPPER90, nuestros socios, estarán justo afuera de Quinn's durante todo el evento vendiendo camisetas y bufandas de nuestra Peña y tambien artículos del RealMadrid - se les recomienda los visiten en algún momento durante el evento.

A por ellos, Hala Madrid!!!

results.description:
The Bitter End Club has been in the Village for over 50 years.

Established in 1961, The Bitter End is the oldest rock and roll club in New York City. The classic red brick stage backdrop and intimate vibe make this historic venue almost as iconic as its headliners. For over 50 years, our audiences have been blown away by legendary artists like Stevie Wonder, Bob Dylan, Lady Gaga, Jackson Browne, Neil Diamond, Gavin DeGraw, Woody Allen, Jon Stewart, Randy Newman, Billy Crystal, Tommy James, Norah Jones, Donny Hathaway, Curtis Mayfield, and thousands more. 

 Many of us remember  "the bitter end" as a comedy club.  The list of comedians that have preformed here is quite impressive.  The club has lasted for so many  years, .............. they must be doing something right .

  Saturday afternoons  is "open mike" afternoon.  We will hear music, comedy, and the spoken word.   There is a $20.00 minimum that must be spent on food or drinks.  This should be an entertaining afternoon.  I decided to choose the Saturday afternoon program because several members wanted more weekend  venues.  I also thought that more of you will come out if it is during the DAYTIME.    If we really like the place we can come again some evening  to enjoy  their night life.

I would like to get out and enjoy some of the classic places that have stood the "test of time" being  in business in New York City......Places like  "Birdland"  "the Copacabana",  "The Village Gate",  "The Apollo" etc.   Let me know if there is some "OLD" place you would like to  revisit, or just check out.  I will say it again...... If you have been in business over 50 years in NYC  ......You must be doing something right ! !
results.name: Classic, Vintage Venue at:  "THE BITTR END"

results.description:
Some people (or person) questioned why there wasn't a beer club event scheduled this week and all I could say is that I'd been busy. Luckily, several years of Catholic school made me feel guilty and then I received word that our good friend Martin from Montreal (who many of you know) would be in town for the weekend and he wanted to go to beer club so those combined forces motivated me to throw this together at the last minute.

Barcade Williamsburg is a fun place, there's plenty of room and the beer is good. So stop by and bring your quarters for some old school video games and beers. Remember, they don't serve food, so bring a sandwich or you can order some delivery when you get there!

Cheers,
Bill

results.description:
HELLOOOOO BROOKLYN! Our last Amazing Scavenger Hunt Meetup in BK was a big hit so we're doing it again! 

This is an INDOOR hunt and includes admission to the Brooklyn Museum. You will receive a series of clues and perform mental and physical (nothing too strenuous) challenges along the way. 

It is a great way to connect with friends or meet new ones. You can sign up as a team (2-4 members) or as an individual and we will partner you with a team. Each member of the winning team receives a gift package.

GET TICKETS HERE - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Nov-21-2015_at_1230PM

What to expect: 


• Admission to the Brooklyn Museum

• A fun day with with new friends 

• Mental and physical challenges

• A memorable adventure with photos

• A story to tell

PREPAY ONLY EVENT (No tickets sold at door)  

*Tickets $30-$35 depending upon when you purchase - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Nov-21-2015_at_1230PM

*We only have a limited # of tix available. Ticket price will go up as event gets closer so get yours ASAP.

Who can attend? All are welcome. This is not an age/ethnic/gender specific event. 


What should I wear? Dress for the elements. Be prepared for a day of walking.  Dress comfortable – Most teams wear sneakers.


What should I bring? A fun attitude, a smart phone if you have (fully charged). The hunt is run through an app called ScanQuest.  You can download that before you come.

Where do we go? There’s no set course. Find your own way. It’s a ‘choose your own adventure hunt. 

What if it rains? No problem, the scavenger hunt is all indoors.

How many people will be attending? This is a multi-Meetup event and we have over 20 groups co-organizing it. We expect up to 40 members to attend.

Where do I get a ticket? You must prepay here to attend. Tickets will not be sold at the door. We expect this event to sell out so please get your tickets ASAP here - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Nov-21-2015_at_1230PM
results.name: The Amazing Museum Scavenger Hunt (includes entry to BKLYN Museum) PREPAY ONLY

results.description:
Waiting List: The day before an event we tend to have a lot of people drop out so do not be discouraged if you're on the waiting list--there's a good chance you'll be able to join.


Attending List: Please remember that the RSVP list closes at 5pm the day before an event. If you change your RSVP to NO after that time or are a no-show, someone on the waiting list could be left out. We take that very seriously.

Club Hours: C&B sets aside space for us from 12:30pm to 2:30pm so those are the official club hours. Everyone is free to stay longer if they wish.

First-Timers: If it is your first time at C&B, you will have to take a lesson from the range staff. If you are an experienced archer, you must at least stay for the safety portion (no exceptions, range rules). Lessons start at half past the hour so if you miss the 12:30pm, you may have to sit around and wait for the 1:30pm. Please be on time.

Public Transportation: LIRR to Hicksville and then a taxi from the station to C&B (make sure to tell them 11 Commercial St in Hicksville). The train from Penn gets into Hicksville at 11:55 am. The cab rate as of 1/1/14 is $6.50 +$2 for each additional person. Those of you taking the train may wish to post a message to the group to share a cab.

Range Costs: Make sure to mention when you pay for range time you are shooting with the NYC Archery Group to get the CLUB ONLY rates:

$7.00 for the first hour, $5 each additional hour OR $15 to shoot all day
$1.00 for a target
$11 per hour for a rental bow and arrows
$5.00 for a lesson (includes first hour)

Visit the C&B website for the most up-to-date information.

See you on the shooting line!
results.name: New York City Archery Monthly Meetup at C&B

venue.name: Read description below for time and details.

results.description: A sampling of the Bronx in its far reaches -- Tour Lehman College campus & view 2 exhibitions in its art gallery, then explore nearby areas of Kingsbridge, Kingsbridge Heights, & Van Cortlandt Village. We will be in pursuit of a little mystery (a shrine) & some history (United Nations beginnings, the WAVES, exemplary worker housing, the reservoir & its parks & fortifications). We'll also see varieties of domestic architecture, including some cozy cottages nestled beneath a craggy hillside. Unavoidable but manageable ups & downs, 3 or so miles. Steady rain &/or slippery underfoot conditions cancel. Bring snacks & water. Meet 12:30PM at NW corner of Grand Concourse & Bedford Park Blvd. ("D" train to "Bedford Park Boulevard") Leader Devra Zetlan <a>[masked]</a>. Nonmembers: $3
results.name: NORTH BRONX WALK

results.description:
HELLOOOOO BROOKLYN! Our last Amazing Scavenger Hunt Meetup in BK was a big hit so we're doing it again! 

This is an INDOOR hunt and includes admission to the Brooklyn Museum. You will receive a series of clues and perform mental and physical (nothing too strenuous) challenges along the way. 

It is a great way to connect with friends or meet new ones. You can sign up as a team (2-4 members) or as an individual and we will partner you with a team. Each member of the winning team receives a gift package.

GET TICKETS HERE - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Nov-21-2015_at_1230PM

What to expect:  

• Admission to the Brooklyn Museum

• A fun day with with new friends 

• Mental and physical challenges

• A memorable adventure with photos

• A story to tell

PREPAY ONLY EVENT (No tickets sold at door)  

*GET TICKETS AT THIS LINK ($30) - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Nov-21-2015_at_1230PM

*We only have a limited # of tix available. Ticket price will go up as event gets closer so get yours ASAP.

Who can attend? All are welcome. This is not an age/ethnic/gender specific event. 

What should I wear? Dress for the elements. Be prepared for a day of walking.  Dress comfortable – Most teams wear sneakers.

What should I bring? A fun attitude, a smart phone if you have (fully charged). The hunt is run through an app called ScanQuest.  You can download that before you come.

Where do we go? There’s no set course. Find your own way. It’s a ‘choose your own adventure hunt. 

What if it rains? No problem, the scavenger hunt is all indoors.

How many people will be attending? This is a multi-Meetup event and we have over 20 groups co-organizing it. We expect up to 40 members to attend.

Where do I get a ticket? You must prepay here to attend. Tickets will not be sold at the door. We expect this event to sell out so please get your tickets ASAP here - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Nov-21-2015_at_1230PM
results.name: The Amazing Museum Scavenger Hunt (includes entry to BKLYN Museum) PREPAY ONLY

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
